markdownRemark.html:
Graph is denoted as G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) where VVV is a set of vertices and EEE is a set of edges, which are 2-element subsets of VVV.

A directed edge (v1,v2)(v_1, v_2)(v1​,v2​) represents an arrow from v1v_1v1​ to v2v_2v2​.

Special Graphs

Cycle Graph CnC_nCn​ is a graph consisting of a single cycle of nnn vertices joined by nnn edges.

Path Graph PnP_nPn​ is a graph with nnn vertices joined consecutively by a chain of n−1n-1n−1 edges.

Complete Graph KnK_nKn​ is a graph with nnn vertices that are all pairwise adjacent.

Multigraph is a graph that is permitted to have multiple edges.

Simple Graph contains no loops or multiple edges.

Bipartite Graph is a graph that has two parts, with edgs joining nodes between the two parts. A Complete Bipartite Graph Km,nK_{m,n}Km,n​ has m+nm+nm+n vertices in two parts and the edges join all the mnmnmn pairs from the two parts.

Wheels WnW_nWn​ are graphs formed by connecting a new single vertex to all vertices of a cycle CnC_nCn​.

N_cubes QnQ_nQn​.

Degree and Order

Degree ddd of a vertex vvv is the number of edges vvv has. A graph GGG is d-regular if all its vertices have the same degree ddd.

Order of the graph is the number of vertices ∣V∣|V|∣V∣ in the graph GGG. The number of edges ∣E∣|E|∣E∣ in the graph is the size of the graph.

Graph Representation

Adjacency Matrix AAA is an n×nn\times nn×n binary matrix where aij=1a_{ij} = 1aij​=1 if there is an edge from vertex iii to jjj.

Incidence Matrix III of a grpah is the binary matrix that has a row for each vertex and a column for each edge. Ive=1I_{ve} = 1Ive​=1 if and only if vertex vvv is the incident upon edge eee.

With a weighted graph, the weights can substitute the binary values in either matrices.

Connectivity

Properties of Graphs

Real-world networks are so large that it's hard to compare them, so we want to compare them using "graph properties".

Clustering Coefficients

Measure of how close a vertex and its neighbors are to being a complete subgraph, where N(v)N(v)N(v) is the open neighborhood of vvv, i.e., graph composed of vertices adjacent to vvv and the edges connecting vertices adjacent to vvv:

Cv=∣E(N(v))∣max possible number of edges in N(v)C_v = \frac{|E(N(v))|}{\text{max possible number of edges in }N(v)}Cv​=max possible number of edges in N(v)∣E(N(v))∣​

Note that for any vertex vvv with ∣N(v)∣<2|N(v)| < 2∣N(v)∣<2, then Cv=0C_v = 0Cv​=0. The clustering coefficient for the entire graph is the average of the clustering coefficients over all nodes. CvC_vCv​ can be interpreted as the probability that two neighbors of vvv are connected. The average clustering coefficient is about how densely clustered the edgs are in the graph.

Clustering spectrum C(k)C(k)C(k) is the distribution of the average of the clustering coefficients of all vertex of degree kkk in the network, over all kkk. Typically, first thing to look at when analyzing big networks is the average clustering coefficient and its distribution.

Importance in a Network (Centrality)

Degree

Nodes with large number of neighbors (or edges) have high centrality, meaning those specific nodes hold some important purpose in the network. This way of calculating the importance is simple, where degree centrality Cd(v)=deg(v)C_d(v) = deg(v)Cd​(v)=deg(v). These nodes with high degree are also called hub nodes. However, this way of measuring centrality can be deceptive.

Closeness

Aside from adjacency matrix, graphs can be represented using distance matrices where entry dijd_{ij}dij​ is the distance between vertex iii and jjj. Degree centrality incorporates the geodesic distance into the centrality equation.

Cc(v)=1∑u∈Vdist(u,v)C_c(v) = \frac{1}{\sum_{u\in V} \text{dist}(u, v)}Cc​(v)=∑u∈V​dist(u,v)1​

where u∈Vu\in Vu∈V means all other nodes in the network.

Betweenness

Betweenness centrality counts the number of shortest paths between iii and kkk that node jjj resides on

Cb(v)=∑s≠t,s≠v,t≠vσst(v)σstC_b(v) = \sum_{s\neq t, s\neq v, t \neq v} \frac{\sigma st(v)}{\sigma st}Cb​(v)=s=t,s=v,t=v∑​σstσst(v)​

where σst\sigma stσst is the number of shortest paths from sss to ttt and σst(v)\sigma st(v)σst(v) is the number of shortest pahts from sss to ttt passing through vvv.

Graph Spectra

Graph Laplacian, LLL, is constructed by subtracting adjacency matrix from the degree matrix DDD, where DDD is just a diagonal matrix with each entry representing the degree of the node.

L=D−AL = D - AL=D−A

The smallest eigen value of LLL is 000, and the corresponding eigenvector is the constant 111. Also, LLL has nnn non-negative, real-valued eigenvalues.

Two graphs are conspectral if their adjacency matrices have equal multisets of eigenvalues. Conspectral graphs don't need to be isomorphic, but isomorphic graphs are always conspectral.

Network Motifs

Networks contain several small topological patterns that are frequent. Different networks tend to have different sets of such frequent local structures, and these patterns are referred to network motifs - i.e., the simple building blocks of networks.
